headline.print_headline: In Israel, Arab Chefs Carve Out a Distinct Cuisine
headline.main: In Israel, Arab Chefs Carve Out a Distinct Cuisine

docs.lead_paragraph: Palestinian chef Johnny Goric has cooked for President Barack Obama and served as a judge on the Palestinian version of Masterchef, a reality TV cooking show. In July, he put out his first cookbook — but rather than publish in his native Arabic or in English, Goric's debut recipes are in Hebrew.

headline.print_headline: World Chefs: Two-Star Maaemo Shakes Up Norwegian Cuisine
headline.main: World Chefs: Two-Star Maaemo Shakes Up Norwegian Cuisine

docs.lead_paragraph: In an unfashionable part of Oslo, head chef Esben Holmboe Bang’s minimalist creations are stirring up food culture in a country where, a generation ago, the height of fine dining was boiled cod and potatoes.

headline.main: In Israel, Chefs Are Inventing a Vibrant Native Cuisine

docs.lead_paragraph: EYAL SHANI gathers herbs two or three times a week from the rock-strewn hills of Jerusalem. Mr. Shani, the chef and owner of Oceans, a small, highly regarded restaurant near the Old City, looks for sage, thyme and hyssop, a piney anise-flavored herb mentioned in the Bible. "You pick the herbs from the rocks, not the soil," Mr. Shani said on one of these expeditions last spring. "When they grow in the rocks they have suffered and have more character."

headline.main: New Orleans Journal; From Gator Fodder to Haute Cuisine

docs.lead_paragraph: Louisianians have tried everything to get rid of nutrias, the big brown rodents that are eating up the marshes. They have shot them. They have trapped them. They have turned them into fur coats. They have even fed them to the alligators. Now they're going to try eating them. Paul Prudhomme, the Cajun chef, busied himself today in the kitchen of his restaurant here inventing nutria etouffee, nutria sausage, nutria gumbo and other dishes. He plans to prepare them next weekend at a Nutriafest, and state officials hope they prove so popular that hunters, who rarely bother with nutrias anymore, will take to the swamps again to provide them for the nation's markets.
